content.description:
Princess Lavinia Catches Fire

Et iuxta genitoremgenitor, -is, m. = pater, -tris astatasto, -are = sto, -are LaviniaLavinia, -ae, f.: Lavinia (the daughter of King Latinus and Queen Amata) virgo, 
visa (nefasnefas (indecl.), n.: dreadful thing) longis comprenderecomprendo, -ere: to catch crinibuscrinis, -is, m. = capillus, -i ignem 
regalesregalis, -e, adj.: royalque accensa accensa = "having set on fire"comas, accensa coronamcorona, -ae, f.: crown 
namque forefore = futuram esse illustremillustris, -e, adj. = nobilis, -e fama fatisque canebant1

Line 5ipsam, sed populo magnum portendereportendo, -ere: to predict bellum.
 1:The subjects of canebant are the Latins who saw Lavinia.↩
content.question: Which of the following stylistic devices occurs in lines 4-5 (namque...bellum)?

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2

skill.text: 2.A: Describe features and functions of stylistic elements in Latin texts.
